newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Chemphil to sell shares via pvt placement.
newsitem.headline: Chemphil to sell shares via pvt placement.

text.p: Chemical Industries of the Philippines (Chemphil) and its subsidiary LMG Chemical Corp will sell shares through private placements to make their stocks liquid, the firms' legal officer said on Friday.
Chemphil and LMG are rarely traded in the market.

Chemphil vice president Rolando Navarro said the private placements would be to comply with regulations set by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that a listed company should have a minimum of 500 shareholders owning more than 1,000 shares each and at least 35 percent of its capital held by the public.
Navarro said Chemphil will sell 35.805 million LMG shares, or 18.5 percent of the company, to 370 stockholders.
Tomen Corp of Japan, one of Chemphil's partners in LMG, will sell 12.580 million shares to 130 stockholders.
Chemphil will apply to list 296,688 shares with the SEC in preparation for their eventual sale.
Navarro said the LMG board agreed to dissolve two transport subsidiaries, Chemical Bulk Carriers Inc and Executive Tourist and Aviation Inc.
LMG would also sell 187,500 shares in All Asia Properies with a book value of 8.437 million pesos, Navarro added.
"We are getting rid of subsidiaries which are not part of the our core business," Chemphil chairman Antonio Garcia told Reuters.
He said LMG had approved a memorandum of undertaking with Kemira Kemi AB Kemwater of Sweden to form a joint venture aimed at producing and marketing aluminium sulfate.
